titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
1. IV:15. Sunday. Attended Church with Charles— Mr M’Cormick, read prayers for the 18th. Sunday after Trinity, and preached from Psalm II.12. “Kiss the Son, lest he be angry, and ye perish from the way, when his wrath is kindled but a little. Blessed are all they that put their trust in him.”— There was not much force in the Sermon though delivered with great earnestness— He explained the meaning of the injunction to kiss the Son: alledged the reasons for obeying it, and made the application by the appeal to his auditors to answer him, with respect to the condition of their own Souls, and in treating them to remember that he put this question to them on the first day of October 1820— After returning from Church, I paid the visit to Mr S. Canning at O’Neal’s Hotel— Antrobus was with him— He has two persons attached to his Legation— Charles Foley Wilmot, and H. Parish, but I did not see them— Mr Canning told me that the object of his request to have a conversation with me, related to the Slave-trade— I left Cards at Strother’s for Mr Worthington, General Swartwout, Dr. Kirkpatrick & Mr Strong.
Mr T. Cook called here before dinner, and Mr Frye while we were at dinner. Mrs Adams was up, part of this day, but did not leave her chamber— Mr Calhoun returned from his tour.

2. V:Mr Worthington of Ohio, called at my house this Morning. Mr Canning came by appointment to the Office at two O’Clock, and I had with him a Coversation of more than two hours upon the Slave-trade. He renewed and urged the proposal heretofore made by the British Government, that the United States should accede to the principle of Treaties made by Great-Britain with the Netherlands and Portugal by which the vessels of either Nation are allowed to be searched by the Captains of the armed vessels of another; and two mixed Courts of Commissioners are instituted to try all such captures— We have rejected this proposal on two grounds; one a want of Constitutional authority to establish such a Court, and the other; as disapproving the principle of allowing the search—in time of peace, of our merchant vessels by the armed Cruizers of another Nation. The British Government have been endeavouring to obtain from the members of the European alliance their assent to such stipulations, but hitherto without success. France has been the most decisive in her objections— Mr Canning re-urged the subject with much earnestness, and endeavoured to answer objections. He suggested that one of the two reciprocal tribunals might be established within the United States— I stated to him that besides the two broad and decisive reasons, which had been alledged, there were others which it was best in candour to mention— The first was the general Extra-European policy of the United States; a policy which they had always pursued as best suited to their own interests and best adapted to harmonize with those of Europe— This policy had also been that of Europe, which had never considered the United States as belonging to her system— The European Alliance, consisting of the five principal powers had since the overthrow of the French Revolutionary domination, regulated the Affairs of all Europe; without ever calling the United States to their consultations— It was best for both parties, that they should continue to do so—for if the United States, should become a member of the body, they would even now be a power entitled to great influence, and in a very few years must become a first rate power in the League— They would bring to it some principles, not congenial to those of the other members, and those principles would lead to discussions tending to discord, rather than to harmony. It would also have a tendency to lead them into partial combinations with one or another of the great powers, parties to the alliance— Another objection was the peculiar character of the principle to which it was desired that we should accede— We had had one War with great Britain for exercising what she alone claims of all the Nations of the Earth, as a right—search of neutral vessels in time of War, to take out men— We had endeavoured both at the negotiation for peace and since to come to some agreement of principle with Great Britain, but had found it impracticable. It was a point upon which more than any other, not only the People but the Government of the United States were sensitive—and which would fix us in the determination, in no case, to yield the right of search, in time of Peace— He said there did not appear to be any analogy between the two cases. By the Treaties the right of search given was entirely reciprocal. It was limited and restricted in the most cautious and precise manner— Portugal and the Netherlands had assented to it; and he thought the objections which we made, might rather have been expected from them, than from France; and rather from the Swiss Cantons than from the United States— That Nations justly conscious of their power had less reason than others to fear the abuse of any concession— I told him that all concession of principle tended to encourage encroachment; and if naval Officers were once habituated to search the vessels of other Nations in time of peace, for one thing, they would be still more encouraged to practice it for another thing in time of War— That as to the concessions of Portugal and the Netherlands, they might be supposed to be actuated by a sense of dependence upon, or of obligation to Great-Britain— He thought this was rather imaginary than real; and that neither Portugal, nor the Netherlands were of a disposition at all accommodating to Great-Britain. He said also that the European alliance could hardly be said to have for its object the regulation of European affairs; at least it was only with reference to certain specific objects— He asked if our principle of rejecting the measures as
concerted by the European allies, was so general as to induce a refusal to co-operate with them in any measure— I said no— We had formed no such determination— There might be a concert of measure, proposed to which our objections would not apply, and that a free and mutual communication of what might be done on either side would contribute much to the attainment of the common object. But I observed that excepting the Communications which we had received from Great-Britian there had been none to us from any member of the European Alliance; and as the objections made principally by France to the British project of reciprocal captures, were much the same as those which we had urged against the thing itself, I thought it right to tell him that this coincidence was not the result of any consultation. There had been between the United States and France no communication whatever relating to the Slave trade— He said that though gratified to learn that we did not reject all concert of operation, he was apprehensive that the expedient which we did reject was the only one that could prove effectual— For so long as hoisting a flag, was sufficient to shelter the Slave-trader from search and capture, it was scarcely possible that any vigilance or care should avail. He added that as it was the earnest desire of the British Government to soften the asperities existing in the feeling of the two Countries towards each other, and was convinced that the same disposition existed here, there could be nothing done which would more strongly have that tendency, than our accession to these arrangements— I said that the disposition to conciliate was perfectly reciprocal, and very earnest on our part— That he must take all I had said to him in this Conversation as expressing only my private opinions— As soon as the President should return to the City, I should report to him the substance of it, and should receive his instructions what further answer to give. He asked if I was willing that in the mean time he should report to his Government the purport of our conference this day—to which I answered, certainly— I called at the Register, Nourse’s Office, to transfer United States 6 per Cent Stocks to M’EwenHale and Davidson, Philadelphia— Mrs Adams first left her chamber, for the last eight days— Mr Cutts delivered up the house in F. Street.

3. IV:30. A Mr Andrews called on me this Morning, to complain that the wall of a house in which his father in Law Mrlives, adjoining the house in F. Street, to which we are about building an addition, had fallen down last night, which he attributed to its having been undermined by Van Coble who is digging the cellar for the addition to our house, and to enquire whether Van Coble was working under my directions or by contract— I told him, by contract, and that I had given him no authority to encroach upon the neighbours grounds— He said he should then apply to Van Coble to repair the damage done by the falling down of the Wall— Van Coble was here afterwards and said that far from undermining he had not dug within several inches to the extent of my ground— That the Wall had fallen because it was only one brick thick, and had nothing but clay and sand for cement, without mortar. This was the fact, confirmed by R. Forrest and others who had remarked the dangerous manner of building the wall when the house was built— The whole side of the house came down; most happily in the night; for if it had been while Van Coble’s workmen were digging some of them must have been killed by the fall— No person was hurt. Edward Wyer was at the Office; and told me of certain Weights and a Scale, which Commodore Rogers took during the last War, and which were destined for Sir John Warren— He said Rogers would lend them to me; which offer I readily accepted. Mr Calhoun called at the Office and I rode home with him— There was heavy rain all the afternoon, yet with close and sultry weather. Calhoun told me he had travelled 7000 miles in the time that he had been absent, about two Months—which is the convenience of Steam-boats and Stages. He went to Montreal, and to Boston; and saw my father at Quincy.— I enclosed to M’EwenHale and Davidson, of Philadelphia the six per Cents transferred to their names— In my Morning labours I have got entangled in a snarl of State Laws upon Weights and Measures— Those of Massachusetts alone upon the subject are not less than one hundred.

4. IV:45. I called at the Branch Bank, concerning my note to A. Way junr. which he had discounted there— I said I had sent U.S. Stocks to Philadelphia, and expected remittances in three or four days, when I would pay the note— Davidson the teller said the Note must be paid this day or protested— I said they must act their pleasure— I did not wonder the Bank of the United States was execrated throughout the United States. He said they had lost debts by decision of the Courts for not protesting them at the day. But if the endorsers would acknowledge themselves responsible, it might be deferred. I said I had not time to look out for the endorsers. Mr Way called at the Office, and settled with me for the rent of the last year— I received from Commodore Rogers, his captured weights and Scales and beam— I found they were Troy weights from 1 to 30. Pounds. but all a little deficient in weight— These avocations absorbed the day.

5. III:45.General Parker, called again at the Office, to enquire again for his friend Byers, if a public ship would be sent to protect the Sealing speculations at the new discovery South of Cape Horn— I referred him to the Navy Department, at which he seemed a little impatient— He shewed me an extract from the London Morning Chronicle of 14 August, republished in our Newspapers; mentioning that this was no new discovery, but land first seen in 1599. by Dirk Gherritz a Dutchman— I had seen this extract before. I examined several collections of maps and Charts— The English have no traces of such land; but the French maps have; under the denomination of Port de Drake— I read the Article “Drake” in Dobson’s and Rees’s Encyclopaedia’s, but found nothing there mentioned of Drake’s Port— They both say he passed through the Straits of Magellan, and returned by the Cape of Good Hope— I have not books at hand to pursue the enquiry. Mr Frye called likewise at the Office, with Governor Clark’s pamphlet against Mr Crawford— It is bitter and presents Crawford’s character in a very odious light— In one respect it has the same fault that it charges upon Crawford. Clark declares his belief that Crawford is confederate with Mitchell in his Slave-smuggling Speculations. This I do not believe—and Clark adduces no evidence to support the charge but Crawfords endeavours to screen Mitchell from punishment— But this I ascribe, as well as the more exceptionable screening of the Bullock’s to Ambition and not Avarice— Crawford’s intense passion is unbridled ambition—and he has great address in his conduct; though he has exposed to so many the nakedness of his heart that he cannot be called very profound— His ambition has been inflamed by success far beyond either his services or his talents; the former of which are very slight, and the latter much overrated— His principal merit is firmness.

6. V:45. Rose by daylight, the first time since the 23d. of August but I sit reading the newspapers now till between ten and eleven of the evening, which proportionally belates the morning hour, and the second consequence is that I cannot get through my task of writing 3 pages on my Report— Mr Coyle came for payment of a subscription to make an addition to the Capitol-Hill Presbyterian Church. He told me they had made a school house of the addition, and had 330 children there at School. I advised him to recommend the introduction of the Lancasterian mode of schooling, to which he appeared to be well disposed. I called at the Metropolis Bank, and found there young Nourse, who had got my note to Way, from the Branch Bank— M’Clary the second endorser had made a minute on it acknowledging himself still liable. Mr Kerr the Cashier of the Metropolis Bank, proposed to me to give my Check upon that Bank, and take up the Note at once, which I did. It was an over-draft of between 7 and 800 dollars— At the Office, I received long despatches from R. Rush and A. H. Everett, and a private Letter from H. Middleton of 28. August in London—detained at the Office till 6. O’Clock.

7. IV:Van Coble the man who is building the addition to my house was here this morning, and at the Office afterwards, but I had no answer from Philadelphia. D. Brent was absent from the Office as usual on Saturdays, and three others of the Clerks, Young, Thruston, and King were absent by illness— I had made a regulation that the newspapers should on the 6th. of every Month should be made up to be sent to R. Rush, C. Hughes at Stockholm, and H. Middleton at St. Petersburg all under cover to Rush, and then to the Consul at Liverpool Maury, and despatched to the Collector at New-York to go by the Liverpool Packets which
sail with great regularity on the tenth of each month— This was the first time my regulation was to go into effect and by King’s illness it was likely to fail— I therefore wrote short Letters to Rush, Hughes and Middleton, and had the Packages made up by Mr Maury and addressed to the Collector at New-York— The incident suggested to me the necessity of another rule—namely, that whenever any Clerk belonging to the Office is absent, his duties must be performed by another, and the arrangement must be made so that each one shall know who is to take his place when absent, and whose place he is to take in turn— These Letters and the despatching of them, kept me at the Office, till the dusk of Evening.

8. V: Fahrenheit at 43 and I made for the first time, this Morning a fire in my writing chamber— We all attended Church. Mr. M’Cormick read prayers for the 19th. Sunday after Trinity, and preached from 2. Corinthians V.7. “For we walk by faith, not by sight.” an indifferent Sermon— There was a comparison between the Evidence of faith and that of the senses. And an argument to shew the necessity of walking by faith, or acting upon credible testimony in all the ordinary concerns of life. This is very obvious, and needed not to be proved— But the assent of the human mind to merely attested fact, depends upon various circumstances—upon the concurrence of testimony and the nature of the fact attested— In Courts of Law for instance, hearsay is no evidence, conjecture is no evidence— They credit no walking by faith, but only by sight— Take the first Article of Faith, the existence of God—or that upon which Paul is reasoning in the context—the existence of the soul after the dissolution of the body; no man can testify it to another— Set aside Revelation, and they are matter of argument, and not of human testimony— As matters of revelation they are to be believed and not to be proved— The fact of revelation is matter of testimony, and its validity may be sifted like all other evidence— This text to be properly treated would require a profound philosophical disquisition upon the nature of evidence— I see in Hewlett’s Commentary an extract from one of his own Sermons on this text— He argues in vindication of Providence for leaving these great concerns of futurity to faith, instead of proving them by sight— M’Cormick did not take that view of the subject— I am deeply absorbed in a search of the State Laws upon Weights and Measures— Mrs. Adams was taken ill immediately after returning from Church, and confined to her bed, all the remainder of the day.

9. IV: There was a heavy rain all this morning— The state Laws and my draft so perplex me that it was near one O’clock when I reached the Office. Received a Letter from T. B. Wait, who is printing the secret Journals of the old Congress, and whose presses are stopped for want of copy— I sent him about 50 pages, but had not time to answer his Letter— There was a meeting of the Columbian Institute, which I had determined to attend, at four O’Clock; but Mr Petry the French Consul General came and detained me till near five; and then I had a Letter to write to A. H. Everett; by a vessel to sail to-morrow from Alexandria— I had a long conversation with Petry on the questions about shipping now pending between us and France— He is full of the project of adjusting the duties so that each party shall have half the Navigation— He brought me a return of French and American Vessels entered at New-Orleans since 1815— He sent me some days since a French periodical pamphlet—Annales Maritimes et Coloniales, containing a dissertation upon the French method of calculating tonnage; and some other interesting Memoirs— I was again detained at the Office till 6. Oclock. Mrs Adams continued confined all day to her bed.

10. V:30. Began the removal of our furniture to the House in F. Street to which Van Coble is stoning the cellar for an addition— He had laid one side of the foundation entirely of brick, which I did not approve, and the remainder is to be laid with Stone— There came visitors to the Office— Judah Lord, who applies for the office of Commercial Agent at Porto-Rico; upon which no answer has yet been received from the President. Lord is very impatient for it, and has renewed many times his application— W. W. Seaton came to recommend
a person for the appointment of District Attorney in North-Carolina— He said that the person now holding that office is about to resign; of which I had heard nothing before. Mr Isaac Hill a member of the State Senate in New-Hampshire came with a letter of introduction from Mr. W. Plumer. He also brought a box containing four sets of the Laws of New Hampshire forwarded by the Governor according to the request in my circular Letter last Winter.— Answered T. B. Wait’s Letter, and sent him about 50 pages copy of the Secret Journals, which I examined with D. Brent by the Record. There was a heavy thunder shower this evening.

11. V:15 The Weather cleared off cold— Fahrenheit this morning at 42— I made again a fire in my chamber— The removal of our furniture continues. My researches into the State Laws upon weights and measures are faltering— Those of Massachusetts alone have taken me near ten days— General Root, of the State of New-York, formerly a member of Congress, and now a very active member of the Legislature of that State called at the Office— He is one of the strongest opponents of Governor Clinton— I suppose he is now here upon some proposed Post-Office contract— I examined and forwarded to Wait, about 40 pages more of Secret Journal copy— The President with his family returned this evening quite unexpectedly to the City from his Seat of Oak-hill in Loudoun County—Virginia— Evening cold.

12. V:30. The Presidents return to the City was hastened by information from New-York, that his Son in Law Mr Gouverneur, has had a relapse of fever, and lies at the last extremity with little hope of his recovery. Mrs Hay went this morning in the Stage for New-York— I called upon General Root at Davis’s Hotel. He says that Mr Sharpe of New-York, will be the next Speaker of their house of Assembly, instead of J. C. Spencer and he thinks that Mr Van Beuren will be chosen Senator of the United States instead of Sanford, whom they charge with being lukewarm, or not anti-Clintonian enough— He says also that Clinton ruined his private fortune by the expenses which he incurred in 1812. to obtain the election to the Presidency— He sent agents into almost every State of the Union, to promote his election, and paid for them, and so involved himself that his friends now say he is in debt to the amount of 130.000 dollars; for the payment of this he is now much pressed, and there has been talk of raising among his partizans a loan by subscription to extricate him from his embarrassments— But the loan does not succeed— Some of his friends say that they would be willing to subscribe to the amount of two or three thousand dollars; but they cannot make up even 50000 dollars which it is said would be sufficient to relieve him from his present embarrassment— Root is one of his most inveterate opponents, whether from greater purity of principle or from less elevated motives may be questioned. I called at the President’s— The mail from New-York had brought intelligence rather more favourable than that of yesterday, from Mr Gouverneur— His case is however considered as almost hopeless— I had not much conversation with the President upon public business— He said he expected the Secretary of the Navy, Mr Thompson here, in three or four days— Mr Bailey returned this day from his visit to Massachusetts. I examined, and forwarded to Wait about forty pages of secret Journal Copy— Mrs Adams was alarmed this Morning by symptoms, probably consequent upon her late illness.

13. V:30. I have got through the New-England States in the search of State-Laws upon Weights and Measures, and this day came to New-York— The Laws of that State on the subject are not so numerous, nor so well digested into system— There has been in almost all the States of the Union since the American revolution an entire revisal of all their Statute Laws— So that there seems to be every where an entire double code— In turning over all the volumes of their Statutes I find, besides the information which I am especially seeking a great Mass of other matter, much of which is new to me, elucidating the history of each State— It absorbs now time, which I have not to spare, but leads me to a track of research which may be useful hereafter— At the Office, I examined about forty pages more of manuscript copy,
and found that a French copy of a contract between Dr Franklin, and the Count de Vergennes for a loan by France to the United States during the revolutionary War was omitted. This occasions a new delay, for three of the Department Clerks are still invalids and absent; Young, King, and Thruston.— The additional building to our house in F. Street makes progress.

14. IV:30. I began this morning the final draft of my Report to the Senate upon weights and measures. I also extracted from the Statute Books of New-Jersey, containing the Acts passed before and during the American revolution, their Laws relating to the subject— The Governor of New-Jersey in answer to Rush’s Letter requesting the information required by the Resolution of the Senate wrote him that there was no Statute of the State concerning it; but he was mistaken— There are several. I received yesterday from Mr Cruft at Boston a Bill of exchange upon the Navy department, payable to his order which he requested me to present for acceptance and return to him— I took it over to Mr Homans the Chief Clerk, who noted its presentation— Cruft wished if possible to have it paid before the time if practicable; it being at sixty days sight. Homans said he had no objection, if it should be convenient at the Treasury— When the Secretary of the Navy arrived he would ask him; and let me know— I also called on the Attorney-General, Wirt with papers relating to the case of the Bullock’s— I found him engaged in the papers of the Indian agent Mitchell, who he said was the most impudent rascal that he had ever had any knowledge of; and if he was not guilty there was no evidence in human testimony— But Mitchell had nevertheless got so complete an ascendency over Mr Crawford that he believed him entirely innocent, and he had written so here: and he Crawford had requested that at all Events the decision whatever it might be, should be made before his return to the City. Crawford’s efforts to screen Mitchell from punishment are marked with desperation— It is impossible he should believe him innocent— But at heart he thinks Slave-smuggling no crime, and suppose his own political fortune depends upon Mitchell’s being cleared— Wirt said he was embarrassed how to make up an opinion, which would not implicate Crawford for neglect— He Wirt had given two years ago an opinion upon the same case in which he recommended that a Prosecution should by direction of the Treasury Department be commenced— Instead of which Crawford wrote, directing that the documents should be all submitted to the Court before which it was supposed the prosecution had been commenced— This supposition was directly contrary both to the fact, and to the recommendation of the Attorney-General; but the consequence was that Mitchell escaped for the time: Rabun the late Governor suppressed the Resolutions by which the Legislature of Georgia directed that the General Government should be requested to commence Prosecutions, and when Clarke after Rabun’s Death did forward them and the prosecutions were commenced they were barred by the limitation of two years. The whole transaction is a succession of malpractices to screen Mitchell from punishment. I called at the Office of Major Roberdeau, with a view to examine the instruments for measuring the Yard and Metre; but he is absent from the City, and is not expected back within a fortnight— Captain Smith however shewed me the Instruments, among which is a beam compass of Troughton—A metre and a yard of iron—two Standard brass Kilogrammes and two Litres; with others which I propose to examine at leisure, if during my public service, I ever find any— I intended to call upon Calhoun, but he was gone home. Mrs Adams called for me at the Office in the Carriage— I had not examined any copy for the secret Journal; but a storm of rain had commenced, and I took the record, and part of the manuscript copy home with me and examined it there.

15. IV:30. The Storm of rain continued all night and through the whole of this day; almost without interruption. I went with Charles and heard a Mr Little preach to the Unitarian Society, who meet in a long Hall over the Baths in the neighbourhood of my house. There were not more than thirty persons, present; seven of whom were women. The Sermon was from Job XXVIII.12 and 28. “But where shall wisdom be found, and where is the place of understanding?— And unto man he said, Behold, the fear of the Lord, that is
Wisdom; and to depart from evil is Understanding.”— The Sermon was an ingenious and elegant exposition of the whole Chapter, which is full of the obscurities of oriental imagery as well as of their transcendent beauties— There is a connection between every part of the chapter contrasting wisdom and understanding with riches, and with learning— It is a dissertation to shew that neither the depth of the sea, nor the bowels of the Earth, can yield the knowledge or the price of wisdom— The preacher noticed the internal evidence of the chapter, that it was written in an age of refinement and civilization; by a person acquainted with the process of mining; at a time when the precious stones were in high demand and value, and when the extraction and use of Coal for fuel were habitual— Hewlett’s Commentary upon this chapter which I afterwards read, did not satisfy me— I finished the examination of the manuscript copy which I had brought from the Office, and sent it off to Wait— Answered E Cruft’s Letter, and one that I received from Josiah Quincy— Continued the final draft for my Report.

16. V:30. The weather cleared off cold, in the course of the Night— Manuel Torres the Charge d’Affaires from the new Republic of Colombia, called this Morning at my house; having arrived last Evening from Philadelphia. He comes to renew his old propositions for a recognition of the Republic of Colombia; and his request for a supply of muskets— He gave me in his way a long history of the campaign in Caraccas and New Grenada, and requested to have another Conversation with me, for which I appointed to-morrow at two O’Clock. He told me that the Agents of South-America, who had been at Gibraltar, and organized the revolt of Quiroga, were now members of the Cortes in Spain— At one O’Clock, I presented Mr Stratford Canning, as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary from Great-Britain to the President, to whom he delivered a Credential Letter from the King of Great Britain, together with two others; one being the Letter announcing the recall of Sir Charles Bagot from the mission to the United States, and the other the decease of the Duchess of York— Mr Canning was accompanied by Mr Antrobus who took leave as Chargé d’Affaires, and by Mr Wilmot and Mr Parish whom he presented as persons attached to the Legation. He addressed the President in a formal though short complimentary Speech, which the President answered with simplicity and propriety— Canning’s speech was high charged, both with compliments and with professions— These are formalities of course; of which I have delivered and heard so many, that they seem to me flat and unprofitable— Mr Canning told me he wished to have another conversation with me, on the slave trade propositions— I appointed the day after to-morrow, at two O’Clock to receive him. Mr Richard B. Jones, sometime Consul at Tripoli called at the Office. While he was there he obtained the perpetual banishment of an apostate Englishman originally . . .Lisle, but whose Turkish name was Murad Rais, and who had insulted Jones. He now wishes that the Bashaw may be authorized to permit Murat Rais to return— Mr Calhoun was also at the Office with a Letter from General Flournoy a Commissioner for negotiating a Treaty of cession from the Creek Indians. There are two Commissioners of the United States, and two on the part of the State of Georgia. Flournoy writes that the Georgia Commissioners claim to join in holding the Treaty, and desires the Secretary of War to write to him, that it can be held only by the Commissioners of the United States. Mr Calhoun came with direction from the President that I should write to the same effect to Governor Clarke.

17. IV:30. This is the first day of the annual Washington City Races— We are in the midst of the bustle of removal— Mr Manuel Torres came to the Office and entertained me again nearly two hours with his demand for a recognition of the Republic of Colombia and a supply of muskets. Torres is a European Spaniard, and has all that patelinage that belongs to the Spanish character. He is withal not a little vain, and fancies himself very profound. The substance of his discourse was that
the Colombians were before this time or very shortly would be in possession of Carthagena, and of all Terra firma. That Bolivar was with Montilla, and that there was a perfect good understanding between them. That Morillo the Spanish General must very shortly be compelled to evacuate the Country; but that the European Sovereigns were hostile to the cause of the South-Americans, and that Bolivar preferred a very intimate connection with the United States. He then went into a long argument to prove that there could be no rivalry of Commerce between the United States and the Republic of Columbia, the only production of export common to them both being tobacco, and that of Varinas being so different from any of ours that there could be no competition between them. That between the Coast of Terra firma, and Mexico, and other parts of South-America, there must always be an immense coasting trade; and as the Colombians themselves were not navigators having neither shipping nor Seamen, the carrying of this trade might be secured by Treaty to the people of the United States— This idea was however indistinctly and obscurely presented—apparently as a bait, and with qualifications affording means of withdrawing from it, if a disposition should appear on our side to accept it. I listened to him with all the patience and attention that I could command, without entering into discussion upon any of his proposals, but finally requesting him to address them to me in writing, which he promised he would— I dined at W. S. Smith’s, and was in the Evening somewhat indisposed.

18. IV:30. I had written and obtained the President’s approbation for a Letter to Governor Clark of Georgia, conformably to the directions received from Mr Calhoun, when this morning I received from Governor Clark a Letter, shewing the whole subject in an entirely new aspect. Flournoy appears to be one of Clark’s enemies, and therefore attempted totally to exclude the Commissioners of Georgia, appointed by Clark, from all participation in the Treaty— He misrepresented a demand from the Georgia Commissioners for information into a claim to hold the Treaty— There is a contempt of principle in some of these Georgian partizans, against which it is indispensable to be guarded. I immediately took Clark’s Letter over to the President— Clark appeals to the promise, which I had made him with the President’s approbation; that there should be a free co-operation of the Commissioners of the United States with those of Georgia— The President desired me to see and consult with the Secretary of War— I called at Calhoun’s Office— We had some conversation, and then returned to the President’s together. Calhoun appeared willing that the Georgia Commissioners should themselves be appointed Commissioners on the part of the United States— This Governor Clark had requested, and I was not aware of any solid reason against it— But the President was averse to it. He thought that as there was an interest of the Union involved, distinct though not variant from that of Georgia, to make Georgians a majority of the Commission would not be right— He thought also there was deference due to Mr Crawford; not to put advantages into the hands of persons opposed to him— The two Commissioners on the part of the United States first appointed had declined— Pickens of South Carolina, last appointed, also declined— Another Commissioner was to be proposed— After discussing various names, the President desired Calhoun to see and propose it to-morrow Morning to George Graham— And it was agreed that Calhoun should write to Flournoy, that the United States Commissioners must communicate freely with those of Georgia—that I should write to the same effect to Governor Clark; that I should send him a copy of the Instructions to Flournoy, and Calhoun should send Flournoy a copy of my Letter to Clark— This affair absorbed my Official day— I was obliged to direct a note to be sent to Mr Canning postponing the interview, which I had agreed to give him this day, until the day after to-morrow. I dined with Mrs Adams and Mary Hellen at W. S. Smith’s— Charles was to have been there, but did not come. He has an antipathy to going into company, which gives me great concern— I am afraid his disposition has too many of the faults of my own— Mrs Smith had an Album, belonging to Miss Lee, a sister of Mrs Gales, the wife of one of the Editors of the National Intelligencer— There were between two of the leaves, a sprig of myrtle in blossom
and three evergreen geranium leaves— There was something to be written in the Album; which Mrs Smith and Mrs Adams after dinner teazed me to write— Such challenges always mortify me, by testing a cold and sluggish imagination— I generally resist them by a positive denial; but this Miss Lee is a beautiful girl— Refusal would have been an acknowledgment of inability the thought of which mortified me more than the manifestation of it could do— I produce no impromptus— I racked my brain from dinner to bed time— Mrs Adams took the Album home with her, and I wrote the following lines to be covered with the geranium leaves, and the myrtle.

lg.l: Leaves of unfading verdure! here remain!
Myrtle of beauty! still thy place retain!
Still o’er the page, your hope-ting’d foliage spread;
Imprison’d still, your genial fragrance shed.
But Oh! could language, worthy of the theme,
Give instant utterance to fond fancy’s dream;
When your frail forms, her gentle hand shall raise,
The page should blossom with perennial praise:
A sweeter fragrance than your own should rise,
And more than mortal verdure greet her eyes.

div.p: I consider this as one of the brightest of my poetical effusions, and it may serve as a sample for the rest. It will at least be the cause of wit in others, and breed better contributions for the Album.

19. V: There was a Cabinet Meeting at the President’s— That is to say of Mr Calhoun and Mr Wirt; and the cases of the persons under conviction for capital offences were taken up— They are yet about forty in number, and confined in various parts of the Union— After much conversation and some conversation the President determined that pardons should issue for Cornell the young man convicted at Newport; for Wever, at Baltimore; for one at Richmond and one at New-Orleans— The rest to remain under reprieve; he also directed the pardon and release of a man at New-York, convicted of confederacy with Pirates, and sentenced to three years imprisonment; of which he has been confined nearly one— Upon this point there was a difference of opinion between me, and the other members of the administration upon the character of the Offence which they thought had been too severely punished by the sentence. I did not concur in this, but as the Marshal attested that the man’s health was so bad that there was danger of his dying in prison if longer confined I acquiesced in the determination to remit the remainder of the term of imprisonment. It was concluded that of the pirates, sentenced at Baltimore, Richmond, and New-Orleans there should be pardoned and released only one at a time— Mr George Graham declined accepting the appointment of Commissioner to negotiate with the Creek Indians; and the President determined to appoint a Mr Thomas Forney of North-Carolina— Mr Wirt has given a second opinion in the case of the Bullock’s of Savannah; which is that further investigation should be had on the case of the Young Spartan— We removed this day from Mr D. Brent’s house at the corner of 4 1/2 Street, to my own house in F. Street— The rest of the family took an early dinner and then immediately removed. I went to Mr Brent’s house, dined there alone, and then came to our new residence, where all for the present, is confusion— I leave with regret the house in which I have resided these three years.

20. IV:30. I arose at my usual hour, and pursued my present occupation of a final draft for my report upon weights and measures— It will still be very immature, and I fear in many respects extremely incorrect— I have not time to sift the subject to the bottom; and if I have the resolution and the perseverence to pursue it, I shall make the report itself only the foundation of a larger work to be undertaken hereafter— I gave this morning the first sixteen pages of the draft to be copied, for the
Report to the Senate, to Mr Bailey. Mr Canning came and spent about three hours at the Office: we went again over the ground of all his proposals relating to the Slave trade— I explained fully to him the nature of the difficulty arising from the Constitution of the United States, to the establishment of any tribunal before whom citizens of the union should be amenable upon penal Statutes; from which tribunal there should be no appeal to the Supreme Court of the United States, and the judges of which should not be impeachable by our House of Representatives and before our Senate— I also went largely into the objection arising from the analogy between the right of visitation and search proposed to be given by the Convention, and the claim of G Britain to the right of visitation and search to impress men— The conversation was altogether free and unreserved; the discussion invariably temperate, and on his part full of courtesy— He suggested various expedients for obviating the Constitutional difficulty—thought that the American members of the tribunal might be subject to impeachment as Officers of the United States—alledged by was of precedent the Commissions to which we had agreed by Treaty to submit questions of property and territorial rights, and could not clearly discern the difference between these questions of property and trials for forfeitures. He contested the analogy between the right of search and seizure proposed, and the claim of search for impressment; hinting some regret that we should even harbour the sentiment that there was any analogy between them, or bring that subject into view at-all, in this case, which I told him I should certainly not have done on its own account; but observed that it was indispensable to unfold with candour and sincerity, all our objections to the proposed Convention. He finally suggested that if we could not agree to the proposals of Great Britain for cooperation; his Government wished us to offer any proposals on our part tending to the same object, upon which I told him the President would deliberately consider the subject, and if any proposal should occur to him, as suitable to be made, I should communicate it to him hereafter— To vary the conversation, I told him there were other subjects upon which I believed a concert of operations between the United States and Great-Britain would be useful to both Nations, and mentioned the Report upon weights and Measures for which I have calls from both houses of Congress. I observed that this was a subject upon which the British Government have been almost incessantly engaged more than sixty years without doing any thing—that there were now Royal Commissioners charged with the duty of reporting a plan for uniformity, who had already reported in part, and were to report further— That they had reported generally against any considerable changes in the existing system; but recommended slight ones, which I hoped would not be adopted— My report would be against any change here, unless concerted with the same change in England, so that we might not by grasping at the shadow of one uniformity lose the substance of another which we possess. I entered into some detail upon the principles of my intended report, and told him I should send him a copy of it, when printed by order of Congress. He had not seen the report of the British Commissioners and I promised to send it to him— In the confusion of our removal, we had no dinner prepared to day, and finally sent for it to Julien— We dined between 7 and 8 in the Evening.

21. IV:30.Mr Saul of New-Orleans and his son called here this Morning; now from Philadelphia— The Son was an applicant for an appointment as a Midshipman in the Navy, and failed of obtaining it upon my recommendation by my not knowing his Christian name— He now came to apply for admission as a Cadet at West-Point; but upon my mentioning that I thought a warrant for him as Midshipman had issued, the father still preferred that he should go into the Navy— He afterwards applied to the President and to Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy who arrived in the City the evening before last— I met Saul in the course of the day and he requested me to speak to the President and to Mr Thompson, in favour of the application— I did speak to the President. D. Brent was absent from the Office this day, and I read the copy of the secret Journal for Wait, till dark, with Bailey— Took it home with me to continue the examination, but took the wrong Volume.

22. IV:15. Walked with Charles to Mr M’Cormick’s Church, two miles and a half. We were late, and heard only the communion service of the day, which was the 21st. Sunday after Trinity— The confusion following upon removal, and building, and repairing the house, with the pressure of my occupation in preparing my report, leaves scarce a trace upon my Memory of what is passing before me;—after returning from Church, I called and visited MrThompson, and his family at Strother’s Hotel— They are waiting for their furniture from New-York, to go into the house which they have taken— While I was there Mr Johnson of Louisiana, Mr Homans and Dr Huntt successively came in— Mr R. Forrest called at my house this Evening with a servant of Mr Roth’s; the French Chargé des Affaires. A coloured woman who lives with Roth as his Cook has been taken up, on suspicion of receiving stolen money, and committed to prison, by Timms who is door-keeper to the Senate, and a Magistrate, and member of the City Council— A shopkeeper by the name of Holmead dropped yesterday from his pocket in the Street, a check upon one of the Banks for 100 dollars, and 150 dollars in bank bills. A mulatto boy of 14 or 15 years of age found the check, and not knowing how to read took it to a shop to enquire what it was. He was then called upon for the Bank-Bills, and denying that he had found them was tortured, thumbscrewed, and hung by the neck (so this man says) to extort confession from him— He finally named several persons to whom he said he gave the Bills, and among the rest the father of Roth’s Cook— He denied having received the Bills; but his daughter was imprisoned, on suspicion of having received them from him. This is a sample of the treatment of coloured people under criminal charges or suspicions here— Roth claims the release of the woman from prison on the ground of his diplomatic privilege; though her name is not on the list of the persons attached to the French legation, furnished according to the Law of Congress at the Department of State— I desired Forrest to see or write to Timms informing him that this woman was in the service of a foreign Legation; and requesting him to discharge her immediately for that reason; and if Timms should refuse, I would apply to-morrow Morning to judge Thruston for a Habeas Corpus, to obtain her discharge in that manner— Mr Crawford returned last Evening from his visit to Georgia.

23. IV:30.Mr A. Kerr, Cashier of the Metropolis Bank, called this morning at my house, concerning some Stock of that Bank for sale by Satterlee Clark. Mr Saul called again at my house while I was absent. Timms last Evening discharged Mr Roth’s Cook-maid, upon being informed of her connection with a foreign Legation; but this Morning Roth sent to request that I would have her name inserted upon the list of priviledged persons attached to the mission, which I thought it best to take as a subject for consideration; as being a native of this Country she is not a person of the description allowed to be priviledged by the European usages. I wrote to Governor Clark of Georgia, informing him of the new arrangements made, relating to the Negotiation with the Creek Indians— Mr Fromentin late a Senator of the United States from Louisiana called at the Office; being on his way returning from Philadelphia to New-Orleans— He enquired what were the prospects as to the cession of Florida— I told him there were no such prospects— He then desired to be remembered if there should be a vacancy in the Office of District Attorney for Louisiana, which he expected; Mr Dick the present Officer having lately married a woman of fortune, and being likely to retire from the profession.

24. IV:30.Young Maury, a Son of the Consul at Liverpool, called upon me this Morning, he comes last from Boston, and is going Southward to pass the Winter. Mr Calhoun likewise called concerning the Letters to be sent from his Department to the Commissioners for negotiating with the Creeks, and from me to Governor Clarke of Georgia copies of which are to be mutually furnished. At the Office Mr Frye came and shewed me a draft of a Letter to the Secretary of War, renewing the claim for additional compensation for the time during which Frye performed the duties of paymaster General— I suggested to him one or two alterations of the draft, which he adopted. Mr R. B. Jones late Consul at Tripole called, and had some conversation with me concerning the settlement of his accounts. He also expressed a wish that the Consul might be authorized to consent to the return of Murat Rais; and promised to write a note to that effect.
Mr Worthington of Ohio came, having been to Boston since I had seen him, and being now just returned. He had seen my father last week and found him suffering with the influenza— This disease is now prevailing in all the Atlantic Cities North of this place and very generally here.

25. II:15. A Windy Night produced a clattering of doors and windows on our lower floor, which roused me from sleep and from bed. We are repairing the house into which we have removed and at the same time building an addition to it; which multiplies inconveniences while my Report upon weights and measures allows me scarcely a moment even for thinking of any thing else. Being once up I did not return to bed, but sat down to my task and wrote till the hour for breakfast. At the Office I received a crowd of despatches from R. Rush, H. Middleton and A. Gallatin— The reading of them swallowed up all the Office hours— Mr Thompson the Secretary of the Navy paid us an Evening visit. We had removed to our front lower room; but I was dull company for him.

26. IV:30. I called at the President’s concerning the Accounts of R. B. Jones— There were several charges in them, which required the special approbation of the Secretary of State. The President thought it would be proper to allow them which I accordingly directed. I had scarcely returned to the Office, when Mr Canning called, and kept me two hours or more upon the subject of the Slave-trade. He brought with him a long written paper, containing what he had understood as the substance of our former conversations, which he said he had informally drawn up, and wished to read to me, to ascertain that he had correctly understood the purport of my observations— He read it accordingly. There were several very important variations in the paper, from what I had actually said; all of which I successively noticed— The first was an inference of his own, which he had apparently written down as an experiment, to see what I should say to it— The remark was almost at the beginning of the paper, and was an avowal of satisfaction that in reviewing the Conversation between us he had perceived that none of the objections which had been suggested by me to the project of Great-Britain applied to the plan itself— I stopped him immediately and said that was more than I thought could safely be said. I had told him there was one, certain Constitutional difficulty which we saw no way of getting over— This of itself was decisive for the present— I had not thought it necessary to mention that there was another, which might prove no less embarrassing. I then read to him the fifth Article of Amendment to the Constitution, which amounts to an express prohibition to subjecting any Citizen of the United States to trial before such a tribunal as that proposed. I said further that the objection to the principle of admitting the right of search by foreign Officers in time of peace, for its analogy to search for impressment in time of War, was an objection to the plan itself— He then commenced a discussion upon this point, and said that I had been so long and so fully conversant with it, that he was sure I knew and appretiated the merits of their side of the question;—I knew that it was on the part of Great-Britain a conviction of necessity which compelled her to adhere to what she considered as a right— When she is at war, the temptation and opportunity is so great for a portion of her Seamen to come into the merchant service of the United States, that without some controul over them, the danger to her was vital and he went through the usual topics of the British doctrine on this controversy— I told him that it was not my wish to debate the point— We had more than once exhausted the argument with his Government— We had endeavoured to adjust it at Ghent— We had renewed the effort twice since the War; and by various Ministers— We greatly regretted that the differences of opinion and of principle between the parties were so radical, that they had found all compromise of it impracticable. But such having been the issue we were in no wise disposed to renew the subject at present; we acquiesced in the result so far as to have concluded to say no more about it— The question had no immediate
practical interest connected with it; and our hopes were that if Great-Britain should again be engaged in a naval War, she would of her own accord give such instructions to her naval officers as would prevent the question from arising— We knew it depended entirely upon her, and we were willing to hope, her government would not be disposed to seek a contest with us— But we knew also that it depended upon the temper of her administration, and that every change of that would endanger our peace. We went over the whole ground of impressment, and as usual to no purpose— His paper concluded with the remark, that if our objections to the mode of co-operation proposed by Great-Britain were insuperable, she had reason to expect we should bring forward some propositions on our part— I told him I should submit the whole subject to the Consideration of the President; and if any thing should occur to him as suitable to be proposed, I should advise him, Canning of it— It was between six and seven O’Clock when I came home.

27. IV:George S. Bourne, a son of our late Consul at Amsterdam came to my house and solicited employment as a Clerk in my Office or in any other manner— He has been two years out of College, studying Law with one of his relations at Baltimore; but has been much out of health— His father was first Vice consul and then Consul at Amsterdam more than 25 years, but never prospered. He formed successively several commercial establishments there; but always without success— He died in 1817. and his two sons have scarcely completed their education— Like numbers, almost without number of other young men, they are coming into the world as Gentlemen without means or resources. He told me that his brother had entered the South-American service, and had lately been here in the execution of an order from his General Devereux— At the Office I ran out two or three hours in weighing several samples of wheat, for which I have taken a cylindrical cup, containing about four ounces. I filled it with several parcels the produce of different fields, and found a difference between them in weight amounting to half an ounce. I also weighed a penny weight Troy by them and found it vary from 40 to 50 kernels. The specific gravity of wheat therefore differs at least to the amount of one eighth; but the result of the experiments does not shew any settled proportion, between the average weight of each kernel, and the weight of a given quantity in measure for the weight of my cup full of one parcel 50 kernels of which went to a grain penny Troy weight was the same within ten grains as the same cup full of another parcel of which 40 kernels balanced a penny weight. But decisive results can only be drawn from multiplied experiments.

28. IV:30.Mr Van Coble the man who is building the addition to my house called upon me this Morning for a payment in anticipation, he having imprudently lent a great part of my former payment to him, of which he is now unable to obtain repayment— My time at the Office was totally absorbed in the reading of despatches— My Journal is running in arrears in spite of every resolution.

29. IV:45. We all attended Church, and heard Mr M’Cormick read prayers for the 22d. Sunday after Trinity; and preach from Ephesians V:14. “Wherefore he saith, awake thou that sleepest, and arise from the dead and Christ shall give thee light.” It was communion day, and the discourse was addressed as might from the the text be expected to those who neglect attendance upon that rite, whom it considered as spiritually sleeping or dead. M’Cormick is always exceedingly urgent on this point, and as much so this day as I have ever heard him— The text offered however topics of higher eloquence than he produced. His argument did not result in conviction upon my mind— After Church we rode to Bladensburg, and paid a visit which has long been due to Mr and Mrs Calvert. He is a wealthy planter of Maryland, and Mrs Calvert is a daughter of a Mr Stier of Antwerp who at the time when the French were making the conquest of the Netherlands, was frightened so much as to emigrate to this Country, but a year or two afterwards became weary of his residence here, and returned home: while he was here however his daughter married
Mr Calvert, and has remained here— Mrs Calvert was unwell and confined to her chamber. We saw Mr Calvert and their eldest daughter— Returning home I left the Carriage half a mile before reaching the City boundary, and walked the rest of the way.

30. III:30. A Mr Canne from Baltimore called this morning at my house, upon private business, with certain papers; but others were necessary for the purpose upon which he came, which I advised him to procure and forward to the Department. Young G. S. Bourne came again to renew his solicitation for an appointment— Isaac P. Davis of Boston called at the Office— Mr Canning came and we had a conversation of two or three hours which began upon weights and measures and thence digressed to the general state of European Politics— I had sent him the first Report of the Commissioners of the Prince Regent, dated 24. June 1819. which he returned yesterday, with a Note mentioning that he should this day call, to have some conversation with me concerning the subject. He had paid little attention to it, and understood little of it. I told him that as it was of common interest to the British Nation, and to the people of the United States; as his Government were occupied in the search of uniformity as well as ours; and as my report contained views somewhat different from those of any English writer upon the history of English weights and measures, and English Laws relating to them, I should send him a copy of it, when published, and proposed to send a copy of it to the President of the Royal Society. He said he found that the general principle of the Report of the English Commissioners coincided with mine; that is they are averse to any material change. I said I had been happy to find them adopting that general principle, and wished they had carried it through. But they did propose changes, which I hoped would not be sanctioned without further consideration. There were two coincidences in the English system of weights and measures which I deemed of the highest importance—One was that the Avoirdupois Pound weighed exactly 7000 Grains Troy, and the other that a cubic foot of Spring water, weighed 1000 ounces avoirdupois— The uniformity and unity of Standard for the whole system hung upon these two coincidences— The Commissioners proposed changes which would destroy them altogether— Mr Canning took a minute of these two observations which he said he he would communicate to his Government— On the present state of European politics our Conversation was on my part free, and on his very cautious and reserved— I told him, I was much gratified to see that the British Cabinet had disclaimed all intention of interposing by force in the changes which had taken place in Spain, Portugal and Naples: but that it seemed to me they would find it very difficult to adhere to that system— There were symptoms of a separation between the kingdom of Naples and the Island of Sicily. Austria was marching troops, defensively to guard her own Italian territories, or offensively against Naples— If the plan was only defensive, would it be adequate? If offensive, Austria must conquer Naples, and after conquering must hold it as a conquest— How would this suit the views of Great Britain, of France, of Russia? how would it stand with reference to the newly settled balance of power? In Portugal, there were symptoms, which threatened the sovereignty of the house of Braganza— Great-Britain was bound by Treaty to guarantee the possession of Portugal to them— The Sceptres of all the European continental Monarchs were turning to ashes in their hands— Their Crowns were dropping from their heads. the very instruments of power upon which they were leaning pierced their hands and sides. Government was melting into its original elements— Would it be possible for England to witness this in all its consequences and remain quiescent? And how could she act in cases where the struggle as it now appears is for free and liberal institutions against absolute power?— He said that Great-Britain had never taken part against liberal institutions, but on the contrary had been contending for the liberties of Europe. But it was scarcely possible to foresee what would be the course of the Present agitations in Europe, but he hoped they would not disturb the subsisting peace. The establishment of Constitutional Government could not only be unopposed by Great-Britain, but would be congenial to the wishes of her Statesmen
but whether the proceedings for obtaining these desirable objects would be marked with the principles of good order and of humanity necessary to render them effectual was naturally a subject of great solicitude— Before leaving me, Mr Canning repeated an observation which he had made to me once before—that he should always receive any observations that I may make to him with a just deference to my advance of years—over his— This is one of those equivocal compliments, which according to Sterne, a Frenchman always returns with a bow— It was quite dark before he left me; but I called at the President’s before going home— It was near seven when we dined.

31. V:15.Mr Crawford called this morning at the Office— I had not seen him before since his return from Georgia— The President sent a note requesting a meeting of the members of the Administration at his house to-morrow— Mr Isaac P. Davis dined with us; and mentioned some particulars of a disturbance at Cambridge; chiefly in the Sophomore Class of which my Son John is a member—

Day— My rising hour has varied from II:15 to V:45. and has averaged about IV— Immediately after rising I set down to my draft of a Report upon weights and measures, and write till breakfast; after which I resume it till Noon— Then attend at my Office till between five and six. Return home to dine; in the evening I read the Newspapers till 9 or 10, and then retire to bed. I have been so much absorbed by the draft of the Report that my Journal is running into irretrievable arrears.
